content.rendered:
The ‘nassa’ is an ancient fishing tool still used in traditional fishing. They are usually made of reed and come in different shapes and sizes depending on the size of the fish to be caught. 

During the winter months, fishermen make their creels by hand, taking advantage of the moments of low activity caused by the cold climate, which is not conducive to safe navigation. 

For the support structure of the pots, the rods (suckers of cane, wild olive or myrtle) are used which have been cleaned, smoothed and made elastic. In the past, hemp or linen thread was used for stitching, but now nylon thread is also used.

There are three elements of the creel: the outer part in the shape of a bell, the inner part in the shape of a funnel, the top of which has non-interwoven reed ends that prevent the trapped fish from escaping, and the lid, which is used to extract the catch.

How to make a creel in the lagoon:

The first step is the construction of the mouth of the creel, which consists of a supporting loop made of small plant fibres from the suckers of lake plants sewn together. 

Then the reed bundles are tied to the mouth, giving the bell weave the shape best suited to the type of catch desired. 

At a later stage, the so-called ‘deception door’ is made using the same weaving technique as the bell cage to which it is joined. 

The final stage is the construction of a lid made in concentric circles, slightly wider than the bell, which ensures the closure of the creel.

descrizione:
The 'nassa' is an ancient fishing tool still used in traditional fishing. They are usually made of reed and come in different shapes and sizes depending on the size of the fish to be caught. 

During the winter months, fishermen make their creels by hand, taking advantage of the moments of low activity caused by the cold climate, which is not conducive to safe navigation. 

For the support structure of the pots, the rods (suckers of cane, wild olive or myrtle) are used which have been cleaned, smoothed and made elastic. In the past, hemp or linen thread was used for stitching, but now nylon thread is also used.

There are three elements of the creel: the outer part in the shape of a bell, the inner part in the shape of a funnel, the top of which has non-interwoven reed ends that prevent the trapped fish from escaping, and the lid, which is used to extract the catch.

How to make a creel in the lagoon:

The first step is the construction of the mouth of the creel, which consists of a supporting loop made of small plant fibres from the suckers of lake plants sewn together. 

Then the reed bundles are tied to the mouth, giving the bell weave the shape best suited to the type of catch desired. 

At a later stage, the so-called 'deception door' is made using the same weaving technique as the bell cage to which it is joined. 

The final stage is the construction of a lid made in concentric circles, slightly wider than the bell, which ensures the closure of the creel.

content.rendered:
Mats were used in various contexts, in fact it is possible to admire different types in relation to their intended use. In the areas rich in reeds, such as the Campidano of Oristano, they were widely used both for work and for domestic purposes.

In the first case, they were used to build fishermen’s huts and also to cover wagons containing the most voluminous grain.  

As far as domestic use is concerned, the mats were made to satisfy different housing needs, such as mats used for false ceilings, as bedding or used to contain grain and cereals. 

In marshy areas such as Santa Giusta, the raw material for making mats is typha latifolia (spadua in Sardinian), which after being harvested is cleaned of mud and left to dry in the sun.  

During the manufacturing process, a sort of frame is made with the help of three wooden or cane supports on which the spadua is placed, joined in bundles and moistened to make it softer. The bundles are then joined together with the help of strings to which stones are tied to facilitate the tightening process.

At present, the manufacture of this product is limited to the artisan sector. In Santa Giusta, the tradition of this handicraft is still kept alive thanks to the work of master Alessandro Zucca.

content.rendered:
he bertivello has replaced creels thanks to its functionality and practicality, which makes it more suitable for fishing all the species present in the Santa Giusta pond. 

The fishing system consists of placing this instrument on the bottom of the pond with rods to fix it permanently.

It consists of six or more elements and is made of a cone-shaped net that is held open with circles of resin (in the past, these circles were made of olive wood); inside it there are three ‘decoys’, i.e. thinned funnel-shaped nets that trap the fish inside them.

The catching system of the bertivello is the same as that used for the nassa and does not require any type of bait, in fact the prey are conveyed inside this instrument both by the current and by their natural movements.

content.rendered:
The use of baskets boasts very ancient origins. In fact, it is possible to admire their artistic representation in various Nuragic bronze statuettes that show various objects of daily use, clearly woven, among which are containers containing offerings. The oldest finds date back to the fifth century AD and are two fragments of rush or straw baskets inside the Nuraghe of San Pietro di Torpé in a layer of Roman reuse

The making of the basket developed enormously thanks to the presence of marsh grasses which are useful for its making, which in the past took place mainly in the domestic sphere. When the artefact passed from the domestic to the commercial sphere, it was enriched with geometric, floral and faunal decorations in order to make it more attractive to potential buyers.

In Santa Giusta, decorations are not part of the tradition, usually they are entrusted to the way the weaving itself is made, and to the shapes that are given to the finished product. Worthy of note are the spiral baskets, which have a supporting structure formed by a bundle of vegetable fibres that wraps around itself, each bundle being sewn with a grass ribbon until the desired shape is obtained.

In the past, baskets were made mainly of typha latifolia (spadua in Sardinian), which was also used to make a particularly soft bag called ‘sa spotta’. Later, other types of wood were also used, such as rush, the tip of the rush (zìnniga in Sardinian) to make the spiral baskets, cane and wild willow.

Thanks to the work of master Saverio Zucca, the traditional craftsmanship of this product is shared in various events in order to pass it on to future generations.

title.rendered: IFE IN THE LAKE – The Western swamphen

descrizione: It loves ponds, calm brackish waters and dense riparian vegetation. It rarely comes out into the open, but at sunset, when it peeps out of the reeds and goes for solitary walks, here it is attracting attention because of its size (up to 50 cm long and weighing about 800 g) and its peculiar colours, ranging from turquoise/blue to purple. This is the Western swamphen (Porphyrio porphyrio), one of the largest specimens of the Rallidae family. It is one of the six species of purple swamphen. From the French name talève sultane, it is also known as the sultana bird. The Porphyrio Porphyrio, the name of the water bird we are studying, ﬂies with its legs dangling, with a wingspan of between 80 and 100 cm, and has a striking shape and behaviour. With its stocky body and short, conical tail, it has long legs of a variable colour, ranging from red to pink, and long, slender toes that allow it not only to climb without difficulty among the reeds of the lagoon's dense vegetation, but also to carry food to its robust orange-red beak, which has a large, bright red frontal plate. The iris of the eyes is also red, while the colouring of the plumage is highly variable: the upper areas and wings are, as mentioned, dark blue-purple with turquoise highlights on breast and neck, while the subcaudal feathers are white. With its life cycle of up to 18 years, the Western swamphen is widespread in Europe and North Africa, but in Italy it only lives in Sardinia and Sicily, where it was reintroduced in 1996. It is present all year round as it does not make real migrations, but is only subject to periods of wandering, usually when young. It feeds on aquatic plants and small invertebrates, especially molluscs and insects found in shallow water and among the foliage. It reproduces with considerable diﬀerences in the period according to the locations in which it lives. In Sardinia, spawning takes place in two peaks, one in December-January and the other in March-May. It nests in reed beds, laying 2 to 6 ochre-coloured eggs with dark spots, which are hatched for about 25 days. The young quickly leave the nest and after hatching begin to follow their parents, acquiring ﬂying skills after about 2 months of life. A curiosity: the name porphyrio comes precisely from purple, the colour that makes its plumage so vivid and fascinating.

descrizione:
The “Fassoni” (Fassonis or Fassõis in Sardinian language) are traditional boats typical of the lagoons of the Sinis area, used by 'palamitai', i.e. fishermen who used the spear and the palamito, a long thin fibre rope to which numerous hooks were tied at right angles.
The boats have ﬂat bodies, about 4 metres long and 1 metre wide, with the bow thinner and arched upwards, and are capable of carrying only two fishermen and fishing gear.
Every year, in mid-June, during the waning moon, the fishermen cut the lake rushes and dried them for five or six days so that they would not be too dry or too wet.
The construction would then begin.
They started with the central bundle and then added odd numbers of side bundles, usually seven or nine, depending on the thickness of the rush.
To consolidate the structure, which was pointed at the bow and truncated at the stern, a framework of reeds was inserted inside the bundles themselves.
This very ancient craft, in use in the Santa Giusta pond until the beginning of the 20th century, was used in diﬀerent ways depending on the depth of the water.
The Fassõis called 'A Cantòi', equipped with a long pole made of three rods tied together, were used in shallow waters, while the Fassõis 'a remus' were used in deep waters and had an entrance for the oars called 'Su Scrammu'. Once at the chosen location, the fishermen would drop their gear (usually ropes and nets) and then return to collect their catch.
In addition to static fishing, the Fassõis were also used to practice spear fishing, hunting for prey.
The antiquity of the Fassõis is testified by an image traced in charcoal on the walls of the hypogeum of the Sanctuary of S. Salvatore in S. Giovanni di Sinis (4th century AD).
Boats very similar to the Fassõis have been found near Lake Titicaca in Peru, in use among pre-Columbian populations.
Although the Fassõis are no longer used for fishing, they continue to be made and disseminated in order to share this ancient working tool, including through manual workshops, involving children in particular, to pass on this ancient art to future generations.
In particular, on the first Sunday of August each year, a very important event is organised to promote and enhance the traditions of the Santa Giusta lagoon: the Is Fassõis regatta.
When the sun sets, the participants, dressed in white to symbolise the simplicity and poor origins of the fishermen, compete in the Santa Giusta pond and the race begins.

title.rendered: LIFE IN THE LAKE – The pond of Santa Giusta

descrizione: Covering an area of around 860 hectares, the pond of Santa Giusta is classified as the third largest in Sardinia and is linked to the two smaller ponds of Pauli 'e Figu and Pauli Majore, which have been a nature reserve since 1989. The lagoon's economic activities are facilitated by the presence of the industrial port, which was created between the 1960s and 1970s and is considered the most important one in the province of Oristano. The port performs the functions of a modern national merchant port and that of a utility for companies operating in the navigable canal, oﬀering them the possibility of independently carrying out their embarkation and disembarkation operations. An environmental and economic resource, the entire area has been listed as a Site of Community Interest because of the great variety of animal and plant species that populate it. In particular, the Pauli Majore natural reserve forms the largest windbreak on the island, thanks to the enclosure created by a dense series of reeds and tamarisks, and allows the nesting of various species such as, among several others, ﬂamingos, black-winged stilts, marsh harriers, cormorants and Western swamphens (Porphyrio porphyrio). The typical plants of the Santa Giusta pond have been used quite extensively since the distant past; in fact, it is possible to admire various basket weaving artefacts used in daily life, such as baskets, fishing nets, mats for house covers and ancient boats known as Fassonis. The technique of basket weaving is widespread throughout Sardinia, as it is part of the body of knowledge that man has acquired since ancient times. The fact that it can be carried out by hand or with rudimentary tools suggests that it predates the invention of weaving, which was instead carried out with the aid of looms. It is an activity that requires a great deal of skill and is manifested both in the manual ability to make the artefact and in the knowledge of the natural materials to be used. The perishable nature of the artefacts and the scarcity of archaeological sources make it difficult to reconstruct the evolution of weaving, although it is assumed that the use of knotting and binding natural fibres was contemporary with the development of stone and woodworking skills. It is however generally accepted that weaving skills were already acquired before the Neolithic revolution.

content.rendered:
An ENDEMISM is an animal or plant species whose distribution is restricted to a specific geographical area. The opposite of an endemic species is a cosmopolitan species, which is distributed ubiquitously throughout the globe.

A particular example of an endemic plant, present in the Oristano area, is the genus Limonium, which includes numerous species that are endemic and exclusive to very restricted areas.

In Sardinia there are about 50 different species of the genus Limonium and in the Mediterranean each island has its own endemism. Some outwardly similar species can only be differentiated by genetic analysis.

descrizione:
An ENDEMISM is an animal or plant species whose distribution is restricted to a specific geographical area. The opposite of an endemic species is a cosmopolitan species, which is distributed ubiquitously throughout the globe.

A particular example of an endemic plant, present in the Oristano area, is the genus Limonium, which includes numerous species that are endemic and exclusive to very restricted areas.

In Sardinia there are about 50 different species of the genus Limonium and in the Mediterranean each island has its own endemism. Some outwardly similar species can only be differentiated by genetic analysis.
ecologia_e_comportamento:
Limonium spp. are annual or perennial herbaceous plants with a rhizome, usually less than half a metre in height (only Limonium narbonense can reach 70 cm in height). Leaves are lance-shaped, spatulate or linear, thickened in basal rosettes or on longer leafy stems. The size of the leaves varies greatly depending on the species. The flowers form groups with 1-5 flowers, and these groups can be grouped further. The flowers have 5 petals and are pink, lilac, blue or purple depending on the species.

Habitat: from the Latin Limomium-ii = meadow, a plant that grows in meadows, in damp places. Plant found on rocky coasts, beaches and coastal dunes, salt marshes and coastal grasslands.

Flowering period: June – October.

One of the endemisms that can be observed in the territory of Santa Giusta is the Limonium of Oristano (Limonium oristanum), an endemic species of the Gulf of Oristano that prefers soils characterised by humid salty sands behind dunes and peristaltic areas that are never flooded. It generally occupies the sandy strips separating the lagoons from the sea. The flowers are between pink and lilac. The fruits are small brownish achenes that ripen in autumn.

content.rendered:
The European Pond Turtle has the plastron (ventral part composed of 12 elements) connected to the carapace (dorsal part) by cartilaginous ligaments that allow the movement of the two parts. The legs are short, with fingers joined by a strong swim membrane. The males differ from the females in their smaller size, concave plate and longer, thicker tail. It is active from March to October, in more temperate areas all year round, but if the temperature is below -10°C it goes into lethargy, sinking into the mud or soil along the banks.

Colour: The carapace is dark and the plate is yellow. The head and limbs are dark and dotted with yellow.

Size: in Sardinia, females reach a maximum length of 14.5 cm, males 12.8 cm.

It is active from March to October, in more temperate areas all year round, but if the temperature is below -10°C it goes into lethargy, sinking into the mud or soil along the banks.

Colour: The carapace is dark and the plate is yellow. The head and limbs are dark and dotted with yellow.

Size: in Sardinia, females reach a maximum length of 14.5 cm, males 12.8 cm.
ecologia_e_comportamento:
Habitat: calm waters, fresh or brackish, rich in aquatic vegetation and muddy bottoms. It can be found in artificial environments such as ponds in city parks.

Distribution: Europe and most of the Middle East up to the regions surrounding the Caspian Sea. Less common in Africa (Maghreb region).

Reproduction: In spring the male caresses the female's chin with the nails of his front legs before latching onto her carapace and mating. In June, 3-6 eggs are laid in a hole dug in the ground away from the water, which hatch after about two months. Two spawns per year are possible.

Feeding: it is mainly carnivorous. It feeds mainly on invertebrates, molluscs, tadpoles and frogs, dead animals and aquatic vegetation.

Longevity: 100 years.

The European Pond Turtle is listed as Endangered by the IUCN Red List. Threatened by the reduction of its habitat and the introduction of exotic competitor species. In particular, of the RED-EARED SLIDER (Trachemys scripta) which competes for food resources and territory.

content.rendered:
The Mediterranean Green Crab has a smooth carapace and a triangular pointed abdomen in the male and a rounded abdomen in the female. The claws are robust with the right one slightly larger. On the head are two spherical eyes on mobile peduncles, and antennae with tactile and olfactory endings.

Colour: greenish-brown.

Size: maximum length 8 cm, width 6.5 cm. Male larger than the female.

descrizione:
The Mediterranean Green Crab has a smooth carapace and a triangular pointed abdomen in the male and a rounded abdomen in the female. The claws are robust with the right one slightly larger. On the head are two spherical eyes on mobile peduncles, and antennae with tactile and olfactory endings.

Colour: greenish-brown.

Size: maximum length 8 cm, width 6.5 cm. Male larger than the female.
ecologia_e_comportamento:
Habitat: a typical species in sandy environments such as estuaries and lagoons.

Distribution: the whole Mediterranean Sea, the Black Sea, and the Canary Islands. 

Reproduction: Mating (from May to November with a peak in May-June) takes place during the moulting period when the female's shell is softer. The male, thanks to his sense of smell, perceives that the female is changing carapace and clutches her with his claws. The eggs remain attached under the female's abdomen until they hatch. Planktonic larvae emerge from them and are carried away by the current. First after 5 years of life, and several metamorphoses, will the new crabs be able to reproduce.

Food: an omnivorous species; it eats detritus, dead animals, algae, small molluscs, annelids and crustaceans. It can open mussels and clams with its claw. 

Recently, the Santa Giusta Lagoon has been home to a new crab, a competitor to endemic Mediterranean crab: the alien species BLUE CRAB (Callinectes sapidus). Native to the American Atlantic coasts (from Canada to Argentina), this species was first reported in Italy in 1949 (Venice Lagoon) and the first report in the Gulf of Oristano dates back to October 2017 in the Cabras Pond.

An omnivorous crab, it is rather aggressive with native species, thus causing serious damage to the marine and coastal ecosystems it colonises.

content.rendered:
The salicornieto (salt marsh) is a natural habitat characterised by the predominant presence of species of the Chenopodiaceae family and of the Salicornia genus. It is included among the COASTAL AND HALOPHYTIC HABITATS protected by the Habitats Directive (Directive no. 92/43/EEC). It includes several species of pioneer plants (variously adapted to extreme environmental factors) and halophilous (salt-loving) plants thriving in brackish soils.

The salt marshes and the reed beds (in areas with a lower salinity accumulation) are the most important nesting and refuge sites for birdlife in coastal wetlands, chosen in particular by Black-winged Stilt, Common Tern, Shelduck, curlews and ducks.

The salt marshes and reed beds are also important protection areas for other land due to their ability to retain hypersaline sludge and prevent salt leaking into surrounding soils.

descrizione:
The salicornieto (salt marsh) is a natural habitat characterised by the predominant presence of species of the Chenopodiaceae family and of the Salicornia genus. It is included among the COASTAL AND HALOPHYTIC HABITATS protected by the Habitats Directive (Directive no. 92/43/EEC). It includes several species of pioneer plants (variously adapted to extreme environmental factors) and halophilous (salt-loving) plants thriving in brackish soils.

The salt marshes and the reed beds (in areas with a lower salinity accumulation) are the most important nesting and refuge sites for birdlife in coastal wetlands, chosen in particular by Black-winged Stilt, Common Tern, Shelduck, curlews and ducks.

The salt marshes and reed beds are also important protection areas for other land due to their ability to retain hypersaline sludge and prevent salt leaking into surrounding soils.
ecologia_e_comportamento:
GLASSWORT (Salicornia spp.) (genus comprising several species).

Herbaceous perennial plant typical of brackish areas, with an erect stem branched into numerous branches that are woody at the base and fleshy at the top. The leaves are fleshy and opposite, very small, reduced to scales. Leaves and/or stems are adapted to function as water reservoirs. The hermaphrodite flowers are very small and grouped in inflorescences at the end of the twigs. Green in colour, they turn red when they start to flower (August-September).

It is commonly called sea asparagus because of its similarity to the common asparagus. It has a high mineral content. The stems are edible and rich in water. They are eaten, still green, pickled or blanched for a few minutes in (unsalted) water and dressed with oil and lemon juice.

In the past, soda was extracted from the ashes of Glasswort and used to produce glass and soap.

content.rendered:
The scientific name of the Great Crested Grebe refers to the position of its legs, which are turned outwards and pointing backwards, Podiceps from podex, buttocks, and pes, foot. The term cristatus refers to the crest displayed during courtship. The species is easy to observe when in water.

Colour: the plumage of adults is grey on top and white on the bottom. The long slender neck is white in front and brown behind. The breeding plumage of both sexes has two ornamental black tufts on the forehead and orange-brown crests fading to black towards the outside. These are raised and extended during courtship. The long pointed beak, pinkish in winter, turns dark during this phase.

Size: length 46-51 cm; wingspan 59-73 cm; weight of males up to 1100 grams and for females about 900 grams.

descrizione:
The scientific name of the Great Crested Grebe refers to the position of its legs, which are turned outwards and pointing backwards, Podiceps from podex, buttocks, and pes, foot. The term cristatus refers to the crest displayed during courtship. The species is easy to observe when in water.

Colour: the plumage of adults is grey on top and white on the bottom. The long slender neck is white in front and brown behind. The breeding plumage of both sexes has two ornamental black tufts on the forehead and orange-brown crests fading to black towards the outside. These are raised and extended during courtship. The long pointed beak, pinkish in winter, turns dark during this phase.

Size: length 46-51 cm; wingspan 59-73 cm; weight of males up to 1100 grams and for females about 900 grams.
ecologia_e_comportamento:
Habitat: bodies of water in wetlands surrounded by marsh vegetation. In winter also in the sea.

Distribution: throughout Europe (including Scandinavia and Iceland), Asia, Africa and Oceania. Eastern European populations are migratory and winter along the coasts of Western and Southern Europe. In Italy it is partially sedentary and nests throughout the peninsula and the larger islands. 

Reproduction: after a choreographed nuptial dance, the pair build a large nest hidden in the vegetation. The 3-4 eggs laid are hatched for 27-29 days. Before the young become fully independent, they can sometimes be seen hiding in the plumage of the parents' backs as they swim by.

Feeding: fish it catches during long dives. It also feeds on crustaceans, aquatic insects and amphibians, both larval and adult. 

Longevity: 19 years (www.euring.org/data-and-codes/longevity-list).

content.rendered:
The Mullet is one of the main fish species fished and consumed in the territory of Santa Giusta. In addition to the consumption of Mullet, the “mullet BOTTARGA” is one of the internationally appreciated gastronomic products of Sardinia. The bottarga is obtained by salting and drying the egg sacs (containing the eggs) which are taken at the end of summer from mature specimens of Mugil cephalus. This is the only species among the Mugilidae that is suitable for this type of processing due to its characteristics and size.

Colour: the colouring is mimetic, light grey tending to greenish-blue above and silvery-white in the belly.

Size: it can reach 1 m in length and 4 kg in weight.

descrizione:
The Mullet is one of the main fish species fished and consumed in the territory of Santa Giusta. In addition to the consumption of Mullet, the “mullet BOTTARGA” is one of the internationally appreciated gastronomic products of Sardinia. The bottarga is obtained by salting and drying the egg sacs (containing the eggs) which are taken at the end of summer from mature specimens of Mugil cephalus. This is the only species among the Mugilidae that is suitable for this type of processing due to its characteristics and size.

Colour: the colouring is mimetic, light grey tending to greenish-blue above and silvery-white in the belly.

Size: it can reach 1 m in length and 4 kg in weight.
ecologia_e_comportamento:
Habitat: it is a euryhaline species, able to tolerate large variations in water salinity; in fact, it lives in the brackish waters of the lagoons, in the mouths of the rivers (of which it can go upstream up to a certain distance from the mouth) and in the sea. At sea it frequents both rocky and sandy coasts, inside ports and near dykes.

Distribution: a species found in temperate and tropical waters all over the world.

Reproduction: Once it has reached sexual maturity (2-3 years old), it reaches the sea for reproduction from July to October. The female releases between 5 and 7 million pelagic eggs, which are carried by the currents. The young return to inland coastal waters, especially lagoons and estuaries, where they find optimal temperature and food conditions for the early stages of their lives.

Feeding: a herbivorous species, it feeds on algae and aquatic plants, occasionally eating small worms and crustaceans.
nome_in_sardo: muggine piccolo da porzione (birimbua), Mugheddu, Lissa

content.rendered:
The giuncheto (in Italian) is a natural habitat characterised by the predominant presence of species of the Juncaceae (Juncus spp., Giunco in Italian) and Cyperaceae (Schoenoplectus spp.) families.

These plants prefer expanses of humid mud occasionally submerged by deep water (which they cannot withstand for long) and can also survive long periods of intense drought. Because of their special environmental requirements, they can be found well-separated from reed bed, occupying the outer edges of banks or colonising mudflats with no surface water but saturated with moisture in spring and autumn.

All JUNCUS spp. species are rhizomatous herbaceous plants (with the stem modified to serve as a reserve) and caespitose (growing as a bush). The spiky pin-like stems deter herbivores and can also protect frogs and tadpoles from predators.

These plants prefer expanses of humid mud occasionally submerged by deep water (which they cannot withstand for long) and can also survive long periods of intense drought. […]

descrizione:
The giuncheto (in Italian) is a natural habitat characterised by the predominant presence of species of the Juncaceae (Juncus spp., Giunco in Italian) and Cyperaceae (Schoenoplectus spp.) families.

These plants prefer expanses of humid mud occasionally submerged by deep water (which they cannot withstand for long) and can also survive long periods of intense drought. Because of their special environmental requirements, they can be found well-separated from reed bed, occupying the outer edges of banks or colonising mudflats with no surface water but saturated with moisture in spring and autumn.

All JUNCUS spp. species are rhizomatous herbaceous plants (with the stem modified to serve as a reserve) and caespitose (growing as a bush). The spiky pin-like stems deter herbivores and can also protect frogs and tadpoles from predators.
ecologia_e_comportamento:
SPINY RUSH (Juncus acutus)

Grows in the margins of ponds, lagoons and salt marshes. 

Harvested at the end of summer, it is used for making baskets, fishing pots, hut covers and the structure of the characteristic fassonis.

COMMON RUSH (Juncus effusus)

Grows in wetlands, fountains and roadside verges. 

The abundant, slender stems were used to make sieves, baskets, ricotta containers, fishing pots, flask covers, chair seats and other items. In the past, the stems were used to make the hole in the tubular bucatini pasta.

SEA RUSH (Juncus maritimus)

It grows in coastal, brackish marshy environments.

Characterised by very long and flexible stems when green, but when they dry out they become stiff and resistant. This is why Sea Rush is suitable for making creels, fishing pots, and baskets.

LAKESHORE BULRUSH (Schoenoplectus lacustris)

Similar to the Rush species. In the past, its stems were used to make ropes (from Greek schoenus) and mats, which is why it is also known as “Rush of mats” in Italian. Also used for the construction of fassonis.

content.rendered:
The reed bed is a natural habitat characterised by the predominant presence of species of the Graminacee (common reed Phragmites australis, donax cane Arundo donax) and Tifaceae (Typha spp.) families.

It is a habitat for many bird species using it as resting and feeding area; and also for nesting, for example: the Western Swamphen (Porphyrio porphyrio), the Great Crested Grebe (Podiceps cristatus) and the Reed Warbler (Acrocephalus scirpaceus). The submerged area is the habitat for reproduction and larval development of various species of fish, amphibians and invertebrates. The reed bed also acts as a natural purifier, as the reed can absorb pollutants from the water.

It is a habitat for many bird species using it as resting and feeding area; and also for nesting, for example: the Western Swamphen (Porphyrio […]

descrizione:
The reed bed is a natural habitat characterised by the predominant presence of species of the Graminacee (common reed Phragmites australis, donax cane Arundo donax) and Tifaceae (Typha spp.) families.

It is a habitat for many bird species using it as resting and feeding area; and also for nesting, for example: the Western Swamphen (Porphyrio porphyrio), the Great Crested Grebe (Podiceps cristatus) and the Reed Warbler (Acrocephalus scirpaceus). The submerged area is the habitat for reproduction and larval development of various species of fish, amphibians and invertebrates. The reed bed also acts as a natural purifier, as the reed can absorb pollutants from the water.
ecologia_e_comportamento:
COMMON REED (Phragmites australis)

It grows in shallow and even slightly brackish water.

It has a slender stem with lance-shaped leaves and is up to four metres high. It flowers in summer (June to September) and makes a rich spike of seeds similar to a tuft. 

Uses: has medicinal properties, various parts can be used. It is used in the traditional art of weaving mats and baskets, to make thatched roofs, paper and even pipes. The inflorescence are used to make little brooms.

DONAX CANE (Arundo donax)

Perennial evergreen herbaceous plant, similar to a bamboo cane, with a large rhizome (modified stem, underground). Probably originally from Asia, it followed the first migrations of man who cultivated it for thousands of years in the Mediterranean regions where it is now fully naturalised.

Uses: it has become part of popular traditions and is used in the art of weaving to make mats, baskets, wind instruments (for example, launeddas, a Sardinian instrument), rustic canopies, windbreaks and horticultural supports. Today it is also used to produce fuel pellets for fire stoves.

content.rendered:
The Mediterranean killifish is a brackish-water fish belonging to the Cyprinodontidae family, of which it is the only autochthonous Italian species (originated and evolved in the territory where it is found, from the Greek autòs = same and chthòn = land). 

Colour: the male’s livery has 7-15 pale vertical bands and a bright blue, olive or brown back. The female has more faded colours. 

Size: raggiunge un massimo di 5-6 cm. Le femmine sono più grandi dei maschi.

excerpt.rendered: The Mediterranean killifish is a brackish-water fish belonging to the Cyprinodontidae family, of which it is the only autochthonous Italian species (originated and evolved in the territory where it is found, from the Greek autòs = same and chthòn = land).  Colour: the male’s livery has 7-15 pale vertical bands and a bright blue, olive […]

descrizione:
The Mediterranean killifish is a brackish-water fish belonging to the Cyprinodontidae family, of which it is the only autochthonous Italian species (originated and evolved in the territory where it is found, from the Greek autòs = same and chthòn = land). 

Colour: the male's livery has 7-15 pale vertical bands and a bright blue, olive or brown back. The female has more faded colours. 

Size: raggiunge un massimo di 5-6 cm. Le femmine sono più grandi dei maschi.
ecologia_e_comportamento:
Habitat: frequent in shallow, calm waters, such as lagoons, ponds and canals. It can withstand considerable variations in salinity (euryhaline species) up to concentrations four times higher than those of the sea. It often ascends rivers and canals, even far from the mouths. A. fasciatus is well adapted to high temperature ranges and low oxygen concentrations. A gregarious species, it forms numerous schools near reeds or where there is abundant vegetation.

Distribution: in Italy it is locally in the coastal regions of the upper Adriatic, upper and middle Tyrrhenian Sea, Sardinia, Sicily and Apulia.

Reproduction: it reaches sexual maturity within a year of age. Reproduction takes place in spring and summer. The male performs a ritual dance to separate a female from the group. She will lay about 200 eggs adhering to the vegetation and fertilised by the male.

Feeding: a predator, it feeds on crustaceans, small molluscs, with a particular preference for insect larvae, especially Diptera, Culicidae (mosquitoes).
conservazione: In decline due to the alteration of coastal wetlands (reclamation works and canalisation), pollution and competition with allochthonous species such as the Gambusia.

content.rendered:
The European Eel is a fish with a long cylindrical body looking like a snake. Its skin is covered with tiny scales and is slippery due to a layer of viscous mucus.

Colour:  adults and juveniles are yellow-green on the back and yellowish below. Mature migratory adult eels are silver-coloured, dark grey above and white on the belly.

Size: the female, called “CAPITONE” in Italy, reaches a length of 1.5 m and a weight of about 3 kg. The male, called “BURATELLO” in Italy, remains much smaller, with a maximum length of 60 cm.

descrizione:
The European Eel is a fish with a long cylindrical body looking like a snake. Its skin is covered with tiny scales and is slippery due to a layer of viscous mucus.

Colour:  adults and juveniles are yellow-green on the back and yellowish below. Mature migratory adult eels are silver-coloured, dark grey above and white on the belly.

Size: the female, called “CAPITONE” in Italy, reaches a length of 1.5 m and a weight of about 3 kg. The male, called “BURATELLO” in Italy, remains much smaller, with a maximum length of 60 cm.
ecologia_e_comportamento:
Habitat: the eel lives in river estuaries and rivers with rock and sediment where they can hide.

Distribution: Atlantic, Mediterranean, Black and Azov Seas, inland waters of Europe. It is a catadromous migrant, meaning it descends river currents to breed and spawn at sea.

Reproduction: once adult eels become mature (silver eel) they stop feeding and leave inland waters to cross the Atlantic Ocean and reproduce in the Sargasso Sea (Central America). After reproducing they die. From their eggs hatch tiny transparent leaf-shaped larvae (leptocephals) which journey for 1 to 3 years drifting 6-8000 km to European coasts, growing on the way and arriving as 6-9 cm long transparent fish known as “glass eels”. Millions then enter the mouths of fresh and brackish water bodies and swim up rivers. Here, they grow into coloured juvenile eels (25 cm), then become adults, and finally mature.

Feeding: the eel is a predator feeding on eggs and larvae of other fish and invertebrates in the juvenile stages, then fish and amphibians.
conservazione: Today, eels are at very high risk of extinction because of their particular reproductive cycle. They cannot be bred in captivity so juveniles are caught on their return from migration for restocking purposes.

content.rendered:
ALIEN SPECIES or ALLOCTONS (from the Greek àllos = different and chthòn = land) are species that are accidentally or intentionally introduced outside their natural habitat. 

If they then, due to high competitive capacities, compromise the original ecosystems, and thus constitute a threat to biodiversity or even human health, potentially generating considerable economic damage, they are known as Invasive Alien Species (IAS).

Among them, the COMMON WATER HYACINTH (Eichhornia crassipes), the COYPU (Myocastor coypus) and an invertebrate, the AUSTRALIAN TUBEWORM (Ficopomatus enigmaticus) are present in the Santa Giusta Lagoon.

The Common Water Hyacinth (Eichhornia crassipes) is an aquatic plant, a swimming hydrophyte. Introduced into Europe in 1823 for ornamental and phyto-purification purposes, it has occupied large areas of aquatic ecosystems.

It is one of the 100 most damaging Invasive Alien Species in the world; its dense floating mats prevent light penetration, alter nutrient cycling and sedimentation rates, and greatly transform invaded ecosystems causing changes in aquatic vegetation and the death of much of the river fauna (www.lifeasap.eu).

Australian tubeworm (Ficopomatus enigmaticus) is an annelid (of the earthworm family) polychaete that lives inside a calcareous tube secreted by it, forming bio-constructions similar to mini coral reefs that create obstacles to navigation and water exchange. 

The Coypu (Myocastor coypus) is a large herbivorous rodent with aquatic habits. Its populations have reduced the extent of typical aquatic vegetation. It also causes damage to tree species by gnawing through their bark and, by moving through the vegetation, can cause the abandonment of the nests of the Western Swamphen and other protected species nesting in the reed beds.

content.rendered:
The scientific name of the Shelduck comes from the French name Tadorne, variegated duck. The common name in Italian is Volpoca which can be broken down into two parts volp-oca, volpe (fox) because it uses a burrow as a nest like the fox does, and oca (goose) because it is as big as a goose. It is actually a member of the duck family, the Anatidae, of which it is the largest species. It has a wide, flat beak with lamellae along the edges to filter water and retain small prey and food particles. The tip of the upper part of the beak is hardened to tear up vegetation.

Colour: plumage of black head and neck with metallic green highlights, white belly and white breast interrupted by a characteristic rust-red collar. The back is white, black and brown. The legs are pink and the beak is red. In males there is a conspicuous red protuberance above the base of the bill.

Size: length 55-65 cm; wingspan 100-120 cm; weight up to 1.1 kg.

descrizione:
The scientific name of the Shelduck comes from the French name Tadorne, variegated duck. The common name in Italian is Volpoca which can be broken down into two parts volp-oca, volpe (fox) because it uses a burrow as a nest like the fox does, and oca (goose) because it is as big as a goose. It is actually a member of the duck family, the Anatidae, of which it is the largest species. It has a wide, flat beak with lamellae along the edges to filter water and retain small prey and food particles. The tip of the upper part of the beak is hardened to tear up vegetation.

Colour: plumage of black head and neck with metallic green highlights, white belly and white breast interrupted by a characteristic rust-red collar. The back is white, black and brown. The legs are pink and the beak is red. In males there is a conspicuous red protuberance above the base of the bill.

Size: length 55-65 cm; wingspan 100-120 cm; weight up to 1.1 kg.
ecologia_e_comportamento:
Habitat: during nesting we find it in brackish wetlands such as lagoons, ponds, salt marshes and sand dunes, while in winter it can also be seen in inland rivers and marshes.

Distribution: Asia (China and Japan), North Africa, North East Atlantic, Europe. In Sardinia it is a breeder, winterer and regular migrant.

Reproduction: a gregarious species, it nests between late April and June in holes in the ground, often old mammal burrows. The female lays from 7 to 14 eggs and broods them for about a month. As soon as they are hatched, the mother takes the chicks to the water where they quickly become adept at swimming and searching for food. They will fly away 45-50 days after hatching.

Food: small molluscs and crustaceans, occasionally seeds and aquatic plants.

Longevity: 25 years (www.euring.org/data-and-codes/longevity-list).

content.rendered:
The Common Tern is called the “Sea Swallow” because of its long forked tail, which gives it exceptional control of flight manoeuvres, like swallows. Thanks to its wingspan, which is very large compared to the size of the rest of its body, and its aerodynamic silhouette, it is able to make spectacular dives for food.

Colour: the plumage is light grey on the back and upper part of the wings, while the flight feathers have a thin black tip. The top of the head is uniform black in breeding birds. The tail is white. The rest of the body has a white colouring dotted with grey. The legs and beak are red.

Size: length 34-37 cm (including tail of 5-8 cm); wingspan 70-80; weight up to 120 g.

descrizione:
The Common Tern is called the "Sea Swallow" because of its long forked tail, which gives it exceptional control of flight manoeuvres, like swallows. Thanks to its wingspan, which is very large compared to the size of the rest of its body, and its aerodynamic silhouette, it is able to make spectacular dives for food.

Colour: the plumage is light grey on the back and upper part of the wings, while the flight feathers have a thin black tip. The top of the head is uniform black in breeding birds. The tail is white. The rest of the body has a white colouring dotted with grey. The legs and beak are red.

Size: length 34-37 cm (including tail of 5-8 cm); wingspan 70-80; weight up to 120 g.
ecologia_e_comportamento:
Habitat: for breeding it prefers lagoons, salt marshes and sandy river islands; it winters along the coasts.

Distribution: it is widespread throughout the northern hemisphere, from North America to the Caribbean, from Europe to North Africa, to the Middle East and Siberia. It is a formidable migrant: The European population winters along the coasts of western and southern Africa returning to us in spring (in April) to leave again in September.

Reproduction: a gregarious species, it breeds as soon as it arrives in the breeding grounds in Europe. During the courtship parade, the male offers a fish to the female to be chosen as a faithful mate, at least for that season. As soon as the pair is formed, it immediately starts building a small nest on the ground which is decorated with shells. The female lays 3 eggs and both parents brood until the eggs hatch after about 22 days. The young fly off about 26 days after hatching.

Feeding: fish.

Longevity: 33 years (www.euring.org/data-and-codes/longevity-list).
nome_in_sardo: Caixedda, Rùndili marina, Marragau de mari a peis arrùbius

content.rendered:
The Western Swamphen is the largest bird in the family Rallidae. It rarely comes out into the open, but can be seen at sunset making solitary walks out of the reeds. It is striking for its colourful plumage and its behaviour: it can grab food with its legs and bring it to its beak. Thanks to its long, strong legs with long fingers, it can climb easily through the reeds and dense vegetation of the marshlands.

Colour: the plumage of the upper part and wings is dark blue-purple, and the feathers under the tail are white. The large triangular beak is red and is surmounted by a frontal shield of the same colour, the legs are red with long toes. The eyes are red.

Size: length 45-50 cm; weight up to 770 grams.

descrizione:
The Western Swamphen is the largest bird in the family Rallidae. It rarely comes out into the open, but can be seen at sunset making solitary walks out of the reeds. It is striking for its colourful plumage and its behaviour: it can grab food with its legs and bring it to its beak. Thanks to its long, strong legs with long fingers, it can climb easily through the reeds and dense vegetation of the marshlands.

Colour: the plumage of the upper part and wings is dark blue-purple, and the feathers under the tail are white. The large triangular beak is red and is surmounted by a frontal shield of the same colour, the legs are red with long toes. The eyes are red.

Size: length 45-50 cm; weight up to 770 grams.
ecologia_e_comportamento:
Habitat: wetlands with abundant riparian vegetation.

Distribution: widespread in Europe and North Africa. In Italy it is only present in Sardinia, and in Sicily where it was reintroduced in 1996. It is present all year round. It does not carry out real migrations, but can move around - usually when young.

Reproduction: it reproduces all year round, with considerable differences in the period in the various localities within its vast distribution area. In Sardinia, reproduction peaks in two periods, one in December-January and the other in March-May. It nests in reed beds, laying 2 to 6 ochre-coloured eggs with dark spots. The female in particular broods the eggs for about 25 days until hatching. The young quickly leave the nest after hatching and begin to follow their parents. They acquire flying skills after about 2 months of life.

Feeding: aquatic plants and small invertebrates, especially molluscs and insects.

Longevity: 18 years.

descrizione:
The Greater Flamingo is the largest bird in its family, characterised by its long legs and neck. When it sleeps, it balances on one leg while the other remains bend under the wing.

Colour: The scientific name refers to the colour of its plumage: Phoenicopterus from the Greek phoinix, crimson red, and pteron, wing. Adult plumage is white and pink. The wing feathers are bright red while the flight feathers are black. Pink beak with a black tip, pink legs and yellow eye iris. Juveniles have brown plumage, grey legs and beak, and a greyish eye iris.

Size: length 120-145 cm; wingspan 140-170 cm; weight up to 4 kg.
ecologia_e_comportamento:
Habitat: coastal and inland ponds, lagoons and salt marshes.

Distribution: widespread in Asia, Africa and Southern Europe. A partial migrant species, it has been nesting in Italy since 1993, with the first nesting in Sardinia (Molentargius) where it is present all year round.

Reproduction: strongly gregarious; groups of hundreds of individuals form dense colonies, starting choreographic courtship rituals (nuptial parades). In nests, similar to mud volcanoes, a single egg the size of an orange is laid. Both parents brood on their single egg until the chick hatches after  28-32 days. The chicks gather together in “nurseries”, and parental care continues until the young bird leaves the nest at 65-90 days of age.

Feeding: it feeds by filtering water with its curved beak which has a series of blades. It mainly eats crustaceans, molluscs and insect larvae. The feathers of young flamingos gradually take on the characteristic pink colour due to the carotenoids present in the small crustacean Artemia salina.

Longevity: 40 years, sighted in 2018 in the Oristano area, marked in 1978 in Camargue (France).

descrizione:
The Osprey is a large bird of prey easily seen in flight, or on a perch in the middle of the Santa Giusta lagoon eating a freshly caught mullet. It is an exceptional fisherman, diving keeping only its wings out of the water making it easier to fly up from the water with its prey. Thanks to its powerful claws, curved and sharp as blades, and its strong, rough fingers, its grip is infallible! At a distance it can be confused with a seagull, not least because of its pale underside colouring, long narrow wings held slightly arched, short square tail, and the fact that it shares the same habitat.

Colour: sharp contrast between the upper parts which are dark brown and the lower parts which are white except for a dark 'collar' and barring on the wings. White head with light streaks, barely crested, a broad black band from the eye down the neck. Blue-grey legs. The beak is black with a grey-blue base.

Size: length 52-60 cm; wingspan 152-167 cm; weight up to 1.4 kg.
ecologia_e_comportamento:
Habitat: lakes, marshes, ponds, rivers and sea coasts. 

Distribution: it is a cosmopolitan species, therefore it is widespread all over the world. In Italy, it is present all year round, with wintering and migrating individuals.

Reproduction: it builds a large nest out of dry branches and branches on sheer cliffs, sometimes in large trees, and also uses artificial nests. It lays 2-3 eggs that hatch after about 37 days, the young leaving the nest 7-8 weeks after hatching.

Feeding: feeds almost exclusively on various fish species, both freshwater and saltwater, especially those living in surface waters.

Longevity: almost 27 years (www.euring.org/data-and-codes/longevity-list).
nome_in_sardo: Stori de pisci, Achili de pisci, Àbila marìna

descrizione:
The Black-Winged Stilt is a typical wader, as its scientific name suggests; from the Greek himas, himantos, leather stripe, and pous, foot and leg, meaning long legs; in fact it has long and slender red legs.

Colour: the plumage of the body and tail is white, in contrast to the black wings and back. The male is distinguished from the female in spring by its shiny black head. The beak is black, straight and spiky.

Size: length 33-36 cm (including the 6.5 cm beak); weight up to 160 grams.
ecologia_e_comportamento:
Habitat: wetlands with shallow waters, salt marshes, lagoons and estuaries.

The reed beds surrounding the ponds are sheltered from the winds and are safe havens for the adults. But, the reed beds can also offer the Marsh Harrier the chance to come by surprise and easily prey on the chicks that leave the nest a few hours after hatching.

Distribution: a migratory species, it overwinters in Africa and returns in Italy, its breeding grounds, in spring (from March to September). Nesting in the wetlands of the Oristano area.

Reproduction: they gather in small colonies to nest, and when someone approaches, the adults take to the air, continuously shouting their alarm and attacking the threat. Females lay 2 to 4 ochre-coloured dark-spotted eggs on grassy islets - or directly on dry ground next to water. Both parents brood the eggs for 25 days. In autumn, they leave the pond to return with the newborns to sub-Saharan regions.

Feeding: it feeds by catching insects on muddy banks and where the water is shallow, but also likes small molluscs, amphibian larvae and worms.

Longevity: 10 years (www.euring.org/data-and-codes/longevity-list).

descrizione:
The Marsh Harrier is a diurnal bird of prey characterised by its slender legs, long tail and wings, and curved sharp beak. It can be seen flying low over reeds and marshes, trying to catch prey by surprise. When it sees prey it launches itself with its long legs projecting forward. The scientific name Circus, common to several species of birds of prey, according to various authors recalls its circular hunting flight. When flying low over the reeds it often holds its wings in a V-shape. It has recently been discovered that some males maintain similar liveries and behaviour to females. Apparently, this is how they escape aggression from other males and still manage to mate.

Colour: there is a clear difference between juveniles and adults, and between males and females. Adult males have grey wings and tail, pale head and contrasting brown underparts except for the distinctly black "hand". Females and juveniles are rather uniform brown except for the cream coloured "shoulders" and head.

Size: length 43-55 cm; wingspan 115-140 cm; weight up to 700 grams.
ecologia_e_comportamento:
Habitat: freshwater or brackish water wetlands characterised by vast reed beds.

Distribution: Europe, Asia, and Africa. Partial migrator: In Sardinia it is present all year round as a breeder, migrant and winterer.

Reproduction: it nests between April and May, laying 3 to 6 eggs that hatch after about 35 days and the young fly away 40 days after hatching. It sometimes forms small colonies.

Feeding: it feeds on amphibians, small vertebrates, reptiles, fish, adult and young water birds such as Black-Winged Stilt, ducks and Coots.

Longevity: 20 years (www.euring.org/data-and-codes/longevity-list).

content.rendered:
The Purple Heron is a large bird of the Ardeidae family, slightly smaller than the Grey Heron. As it is most active at dusk and dawn it is more difficult to see than other heron species, and it is also  rarer. When flying it assumes the S-shaped neck posture typical of herons.

Colour: it varies from grey on the back to reddish-brown on the underside. Its neck is reddish with black streaks and it has two threadlike feathers on its head. The beak is blue-black and the legs are pink during the breeding season.

Size: length (with the neck extended) 70-90 cm; wingspan 120-138 cm; weight up to 1.1 kg.

descrizione:
The Purple Heron is a large bird of the Ardeidae family, slightly smaller than the Grey Heron. As it is most active at dusk and dawn it is more difficult to see than other heron species, and it is also  rarer. When flying it assumes the S-shaped neck posture typical of herons.

Colour: it varies from grey on the back to reddish-brown on the underside. Its neck is reddish with black streaks and it has two threadlike feathers on its head. The beak is blue-black and the legs are pink during the breeding season.

Size: length (with the neck extended) 70-90 cm; wingspan 120-138 cm; weight up to 1.1 kg.
ecologia_e_comportamento:
Habitat: freshwater wetlands with reeds.

Distribution: Eurasia, Africa and Indonesia. It is a regular migrant; it spends the winter in Africa south of the Sahara and in spring returns to Italy where it nests and stays until late summer.

Reproduction: the Purple Heron nests between the end of April and the beginning of May, in small colonies, sometimes together with other Ardeidae present in the Santa Giusta lagoon, such as the Grey Heron, Great Egret, Squacco Heron and Night Heron. It builds its nest in the reeds or among the vegetation, at a height of 0.5-1 m from the water, or in trees 25 m from the ground. It lays 4-5 blue/green eggs with white spots. After about a month they hatch, and it takes 45-50 days for the young to start flying. Both parents look after the young until they fly away.

Food: fish, frogs, insects (both larvae and adults). It can also feed on crustaceans and molluscs and occasionally eats small mammals and reptiles.

Longevity: 25 years (www.euring.org/data-and-codes/longevity-list).

content.rendered:
The common name alludes to its great ability to catch fish by diving. It darts about quickly, flying low over the surface of the water and emitting a high-pitched whistle. In addition to being a formidable fisherman, it is also a “miner”; thanks to the particular conformation of its legs, with two fingers joined together to act as a “shovel”, it digs long tunnels in sandy banks.

Colour: on the head, back and wings, the plumage is intense bright blue-green, cobalt blue on the back, while the cheeks and underparts are a bright orange. The legs are red, and the beak and irises are black. Juveniles are similar to adults but have duller colours and darker legs.

Size: length 17-19 cm (including the beak of about 4 cm); weight up to 40 grams.

In addition to being a formidable fisherman, it is also a "miner"; thanks to the particular conformation of its legs, with two fingers joined together to act as a "shovel", it digs long tunnels in sandy banks.

Colour: on the head, back and wings, the plumage is intense bright blue-green, cobalt blue on the back, while the cheeks and underparts are a bright orange. The legs are red, and the beak and irises are black. Juveniles are similar to adults but have duller colours and darker legs.

ecologia_e_comportamento:
Habitat: waterbodies, even small ones, provided they are rich in fish and have calm and clear waters, ponds, rivers, lagoons. It frequents sea coasts during wintering.

Distribution: present and sedentary in Italy all year round, it can make seasonal movements if the waters in its territory freeze over or if their water level falls too low. In winter, Italy also hosts wintering contingents from Central and Eastern Europe.

Reproduction: it nests in April in sandy or slightly clayey walls where the Kingfisher digs a tunnel, often uphill for protection in the event of flooding, up to a metre long and ending in a spherical chamber. In this chamber, the female lays 6-7 eggs and both parents brood until hatching after  about 20 days. The young leave the nest 27 days after hatching.

Feeding: small fish which it catches and kills by banging them against a perch.

Longevity: 21 years (www.euring.org/data-and-codes/longevity-list).
nome_in_sardo: Pudzòne de Santu Martìnu, Pedru piscadòri, Pillòni de Santu Perdu

content.rendered:
The Santa Giusta Fishermen’s Cooperative, activities and history

The pond of Santa Giusta is in concession to the Cooperativa Pescatori Santa Giusta, which first started at the beginning of the 1950s. 

From 1946 to 1949 the pond and the fishponds of Santa Giusta were granted to the Santa Giusta Cooperative, after which, until 1975, the cooperative formed a consortium with those of Santa Rita and San Pietro, under the technical direction of Cenzo Loi, with the aim of carrying out reclamation works to increase the fish fauna, improve the working conditions of the fishermen and increase the inflow and outflow of the water. 

Thanks to the active participation of the fishermen and funding from the Region, it was possible to arrange the pond’s inlets to the sea, where the lavorieri and the fishpond were installed; in the 1950s the pond became the most high yielding in Europe. In spite of these productive achievements, the working conditions of the fishermen did not improve, and 1958 saw numerous unrests. In the meantime, the cooperative remained inactive and isolated from the rest of the consortium in the hope of being able to reobtain the management of the pond. After being unfulfilled for another nine years, it finally came about on 7 January 1975, when the concession was not renewed and the two cooperatives of S. Pietro and S. Rita were dissolved and merged into that of Santa Giusta. 

At present, the Santa Giusta fishermen’s cooperative is responsible for fishing in the pond, where fixed and roving equipment is used to guarantee a catch consisting mainly of eels, carp, mussels, sea bass, gilthead bream, crabs and silversides.

Among the various activities carried out by the cooperative is the management of the “Su Fassoi” ichthyic-tourism, which is closely linked to fishing activities, boat trips and the dissemination of the tradition linked to Is Fassõis.

content.rendered:
Fishing activity in the pond of Santa Giusta

The pond of Santa Giusta, thanks to its direct connection with the sea through the Pesaria canal, is the ideal environment for bream, bass, eels and mullet.

From the 1980s to the 1990s a large project of the Region was implemented to dredge the pond of Santa Giusta with a 50-metre wide channel. 

A channel of the industrial port was opened in the embankment, which has never been closed. When the freshwater supply was cut off, the pond was transformed into a lagoon by the injection of salt water directly from the sea. 

This change resulted in the alteration of the fish fauna by eliminating freshwater fish such as carp and drastically reducing the presence of eels.  On the other hand, there has been an increase in the quantity of gilthead seabream (around 900-1000 quintals caught), clams, red mullet, crabs and sole. The pond is in concession to the Cooperativa Pescatori Santa Giusta.

content.rendered:
The antiquity of the fassõis is testified by an image traced in charcoal on the walls of the hypogeum of the Sanctuary of S. Salvatore in S. Giovanni di Sinis (4th century AD).

Boats very similar to fassõis have been found near Lake Titicaca in Peru in use by pre-Columbian populations.

During the regatta of Is fassõis, the competing fishermen are dressed in white to symbolise the simplicity and poor origins of the ancient fishermen who, unable to afford ready-made clothes, used scraps of white cloth (information kindly provided by Marco Pili, vice president of the Santa Giusta fishermen’s cooperative).

Although fassõis are no longer used for fishing, they continue to be made and disseminated in order to share this ancient work tool. To this end, workshops are also set up involving children in particular in order to pass on this ancient art to future generations.

Boats very similar to fassõis have been found near Lake Titicaca in Peru in use by pre-Columbian populations. During the regatta of […]

meta._et_pb_old_content:
1. VITA NELLA LAGUNA -  Curiosità e testimonianze

L’antichità dei fassõis è testimoniata da un’immagine tracciata a carboncino sulle pareti dell’ipogeo del Santuario di S. Salvatore a S. Giovanni di Sinis (IV sec. d.C.).

Barche molto simili ai fassõis sono state rinvenute presso il lago Titicaca in Perù in uso presso le popolazioni precolombiane.

Durante la regata de Is fassõis i pescatori che gareggiano sono vestiti di bianco per simboleggiare la semplicità e le povere origini degli antichi operatori della pesca che, non potendosi permettere abiti confezionati, utilizzavano ritagli di stoffa bianca (notizia gentilmente trasmessa da Marco Pili, vice presidente della cooperativa pescatori Santa Giusta).

Anche se i  fassõis non sono più utilizzati per la pesca, continuano ad essere realizzati e diffusi al fine di condividere questo antico strumento di lavoro. A tal proposito vengono anche creati dei laboratori che coinvolgono soprattutto i bambini al fine di tramandare questa antica arte alle future generazioni.

descrizione:
The antiquity of the fassõis is testified by an image traced in charcoal on the walls of the hypogeum of the Sanctuary of S. Salvatore in S. Giovanni di Sinis (4th century AD).

Boats very similar to fassõis have been found near Lake Titicaca in Peru in use by pre-Columbian populations.

During the regatta of Is fassõis, the competing fishermen are dressed in white to symbolise the simplicity and poor origins of the ancient fishermen who, unable to afford ready-made clothes, used scraps of white cloth (information kindly provided by Marco Pili, vice president of the Santa Giusta fishermen's cooperative).

Although fassõis are no longer used for fishing, they continue to be made and disseminated in order to share this ancient work tool. To this end, workshops are also set up involving children in particular in order to pass on this ancient art to future generations.

content.rendered:
Weaving in the maritime tradition

The art of weaving is used in different contexts, including fishing, which has always required equipment for the catch that can withstand the force of the fish themselves.

The main characteristics of the “snares” must be such as to balance resistance and invisibility. Of course, over the years fishing techniques have been refined because the fish have learnt to defend themselves against “predators”, so fishing operators have adapted to their evolution by studying new methods and materials that have less and less impact on the environment in which they operate.

Among the traditional maritime tools made using the art of weaving, the most important ones are nets, creels, fassõis, the bonito basket and baskets for transporting fish. 

Nets are common in all coastal fishing areas and differ in size and mesh size depending on the catch. After harvesting, the reed was left to dry in the sun in ventilated and dry places. The supporting structure of the nasse was made from suckers of wild olive, myrtle or cleaned and smoothed reeds, while the stitching was made with hemp or linen thread (nowadays the more practical and resistant nylon thread is used).

The structure of creels is made up of three basic elements, the bell, which is the external part that makes up the structure, the deception door, which is the funnel-shaped internal part that allows the fish to enter but prevents it from coming out, and finally the lid that closes the structure of the tool, useful for extracting the catch.

content.rendered:
WEAVING AND HANDICRAFTS

Weaving is the basis of many handicrafts, which are seen nowadays, both in the direct sale by the craftsmen who contribute to handing down this ancient art, and in the ethnographic museums, where it is possible to admire the various types made in different regional areas. Modern craftsmen and these places of remembrance offer the possibility of admiring those artefacts from the past, especially those belonging to furnishing accessories, which are no longer in common use because they have been replaced by modern mass-produced products that are cheaper but less attractive.

In the past, thanks to this ancient technique, Sardinian families were able to make many everyday items using natural animal and vegetable fibres. A typical example is the use of woven reeds, sedge or other lake plants which have made roofs and huts since the Neolithic age (4th millennium B.C.). The Oristanese area, being rich in grasses and marshes, where it is possible to find the raw materials for making artefacts, has in fact yielded numerous archaeological testimonies relating to the use of these materials.

In Santa Giusta, woven handicraft production is characterised above all by the creation of baskets (made for domestic and working activities), mats (for making beds, for paving many dwellings in the past or for agricultural activities), Easter palms (for the typical processing of the so-called ‘religious weaving’) and tools used for fishing in the pond.

content.rendered:
WEAVING COMPOSITIONAL TECHNIQUES

In Sardinia, there are mainly two different weaving techniques, spiral and cross structures.  In the first case, weaving is carried out by starting with a spiral warp around which the vegetable fibre is wound and sewn with firm, spiral-shaped stitches with the aid of a perforating tool. The typical Campidanese and Logudorese name for this type of technique is ‘strexiu ‘e fenu’. The baskets that are made with this technique differ from each other in relation to the plant materials used, in the Campidano di Oristano area the warp is typically made from heaps of wheat and the weft from rush fibres.

In criss-cross structures, the weft fibres are passed through the warp in different directions, alternating from the bottom to the top, depending on the final result to be obtained. This technique is typical of rustic and work baskets, creels, special coverings for bottles and other furnishing objects. The tools used during manufacture are shears, which are useful for cutting off the residue from the work and for finishing the fibres of the warp, the knife (s’arresoia) for removing superfluous parts and the billhook for cutting and pointing out the thicker slats and for finishing the work carried out.

The weavings also change according to their use, we have in fact those related to building and daily use for the construction of roofs, mats, the bottoms of chairs typical in Sardinian kitchens and baskets for bread, those typical of sacred ceremonies such as the palm tree for Easter and those used for daily work activities such as pots for fishing.

The typical Campidanese and Logudorese […]

content.rendered:
MATERIALS AND TOOLS USED IN THE WEAVING TECHNIQUE

The materials used for weaving are readily available in nature and are typical of the areas in which the artefacts are made. These include both vegetable fibres, such as marsh grasses, graminaceous plants, leaves, bark and branches, and animal fibres, such as hair, horsehair, wool, feathers, sinews and skins.

In addition to the operational skills of tying, twisting and knotting materials, specific skills such as knowledge of the life cycle of the grasses, plants and animals to be used, as well as their physical properties such as flexibility, elasticity and plasticity, are essential for the creation of artefacts.  

Manual weaving requires not only a knife to cut and fray the material, but also an awl or burr to pierce the elements in the spiral process.

content.rendered:
The pond of Santa Giusta, with its extension of about 860 hectares, is classified as the third largest in Sardinia and is connected to the two smaller ponds of Pauli ‘e Figu and Pauli Majore, a nature reserve since 1989. 

Thanks to the animal and plant species that characterise it, it is included among the sites of Community interest; the Pauli Majore nature reserve, forming the largest windbreak on the island thanks to the enclosure created by a dense series of reeds and tamarisks, in fact, allows the nesting of various species such as flamingos, black-winged stilts, marsh harriers, cormorants, Sultan chickens, etc.

The typical plants of the pond of Santa Giusta have been used since the most distant past; in fact, it is possible to admire various artefacts made by weaving and used in daily life, such as baskets, fishing nets, mats for house covers and ancient boats better known as Fassonis.

Economic activities are facilitated by the presence of the industrial port, considered to be the most important in the province of Oristano, protected by a pier, and within which there is a dock housing two fixed docks along with a floating one.

The industrial port, which came into being between the 1960s and 1970s, thanks to its contiguity with the industrial area, performs both the functions of a modern commercial port, equipped with a high level of services and areas for handling goods, and those of a utility for businesses, which are located along the navigable canal, with the possibility of carrying out embarkation and disembarkation operations independently.

content.rendered:
VITA NELLA LAGUNA – Tecniche compositive dell’intreccio

In Sardegna esistono principalmente due diverse tecniche compositive, le strutture a spirale e le strutture ad incrocio. 

Nel primo caso la lavorazione si realizza partendo da un ordito a spirale intorno al quale viene avvolta e cucita  con punti fermi e spiraliformi la fibra vegetale con l’ausilio di uno strumento perforante.

La denominazione tipica campidanese e logudorese di questo tipo di tecnica è “strexiu ‘e fenu”.

I cesti che si realizzano con questa tecnica differiscono tra loro in relazione ai materiali vegetali utilizzati, nel campidano di Oristano è tipico l’ordito in cumuli di grano e trama in fibre di giunco.

Nelle strutture ad incrocio attraverso l’ordito si fanno passare le fibre di trama che seguono direzioni differenti alternate dal basso verso l’alto in base al risultato finale che si vuole ottenere.

Questa tecnica è tipica dei cesti rustici e da lavoro, delle nasse, dei rivestimenti particolari per bottiglie e altri oggetti d’arredo.

Gli attrezzi impiegati durante la lavorazione sono le cesoie, utili per tagliare i residui della lavorazione e per rifinire le fibre dell’ordito, il coltello (s’arresoia) per asportare le parti superflue e la roncola per tagliare e appuntire le stecche più grosse e per rifinire il lavoro realizzato.

Gli intrecci cambiano anche in base alla loro destinazione, abbiamo infatti quelli relativi all’edilizia e all’uso quotidiano per la realizzazione di i tetti, stuoie,  fondi delle sedie tipiche della cucina sarda e cesti per il pane,  quelli tipici dei cerimoniali sacri come la palma per la Pasqua  e quelli preposti alle attività lavorative quotidiane come le nasse per la pesca.

content.rendered:
Braiding is widespread throughout Sardinia. The technique of weaving is part of the wealth of knowledge that man has acquired since ancient times. The fact that it can be carried out by hand or with rudimentary tools, suggests that it precedes weaving, which is carried out with the aid of looms used to tension or suspend the warp threads.

This activity requires a great deal of skill, which is manifested both in the manual ability to produce the artefact and in the knowledge of the natural materials to be used.

The scarcity of archaeological sources makes it difficult to reconstruct the evolution of this technique, even if it is assumed that the use of knotting and binding natural fibres was contemporary with the development of stone and woodworking skills; in any case, it is a common opinion that weaving skills had already been acquired before the Neolithic revolution. The perishable nature of woven artefacts makes it even more difficult to date the oldest evidence.

This activity requires a great deal of skill, which is manifested both in the manual ability to produce the artefact and in the knowledge of the natural materials to be used.

The scarcity of archaeological sources makes it difficult to reconstruct the evolution of this technique, even if it is assumed that the use of knotting and binding natural fibres was contemporary with the development of stone and woodworking skills; in any case, it is a common opinion that weaving skills had already been acquired before the Neolithic revolution. The perishable nature of woven artefacts makes it even more difficult to date the oldest evidence.

content.rendered:
Like all productive activities, fishing has undergone a process of modernisation with techniques that have been refined over the course of its very long history. Generally speaking, unlike other activities, the modernisation of fishing has been limited to the use of different materials, leaving intact its original sector in terms of the techniques used.

This process has, of course, also involved the Santa Giusta pond; its professional fishermen, despite the use of traditional tools, have, in fact, made innovations relating mainly to the materials used in their manufacture. All tools needed for fishing used to be made from natural fibres by the members of each fisherman’s family, but nowadays synthetic fibres have replaced natural ones.

Some of the tools of the past are no longer used because they have been replaced by others that are better suited to modern requirements, such as the nasse (‘sa nassa’ in Sardinian) for fishing eels, which have now been replaced by the more practical and functional bertivello (‘sa mattavella’ in Sardinian) that guarantees a larger and therefore more profitable catch.

content.rendered:
Nets are made of crossed threads, knotted together at regular intervals to create rhomboidal meshes whose size and strength vary according to their use. The fibres used for weaving are hemp, coconut, horsehair and other materials according to the different types and geographical area of manufacture.  In the Santa Giusta pond the raw material used in the past was cotton, but the perishable nature of this fibre required special treatments to waterproof the nets themselves, which were immersed in tar. Nowadays this problem has been overcome thanks to the use of nylon for their production, the resistance of this fibre allows a longer duration.

Before the use of synthetic fibres, the nets were woven by hand using a so-called “net needle” made of wood or metal; nowadays the use of this tool is limited to any repairs needed to the nets, which are bought ready-made.

content.rendered:
– The trammel net

The trammel net is a gill net made up of three layers with decreasing mesh size (the outer layer has the largest mesh and the inner layer has the smallest one). The net is lowered at the points most frequented by fish in such a way as to block their passage and ensure that they are imprisoned by the narrow meshes of the inner part. 

– The seine

The seine is a trawl used in shallow waters. This net is dragged by hand or with small boats and in their passage they capture all they encounter.

– The speargun

The spear is usually a trident mounted on a long stick that is used in shallow waters from above a small boat. It allows the capture of fish that is spotted.
