title.rendered: Ancient fishing techniques still used today

content.rendered:
– S’apparecchiu

S’apparecchiu is made up of two parallel boats joined together and spaced out by poles; at the bow and stern of the two boats is a rectangular net mounted on a frame that emerges from the water. The boats are manoeuvred slowly and their shadows and movements induce the fish (especially mullet) to jump out of the water and into the trap.

– Fishing with colleagues

This technique involves the use of four boats arranged in parallel two by two. A surrounding net is placed on the prows of each pair of boats, and the fish are trapped in it, frightened both by the shadows of the boats and by the beating that the fishermen make on the boats themselves with sticks.

– Hook fishing

Fishing with hooks is carried out with the “cannete” and the “palamito or parangale”. In the first case, thin rods with lines and baited hooks are used, which are fixed to the bottom of the pond at dusk. When the sun rises, the equipment is checked and, if there is a bite, the fish is hauled in and the baited hook is re-set. The ‘palamito’, on the other hand, is a long line with numerous baited hooks that is lowered while waiting for the catch, and can have more than 200 hooks. In contrast to a ‘reed boat’, a longline is completely hauled in, re-trimmed and lowered while waiting for a new catch.

This technique involves the use of four boats arranged in parallel two by two. A surrounding net is placed on the prows of each pair of boats, and the fish are trapped in it, frightened both by the shadows of the boats and by the beating that the fishermen make on the boats themselves with sticks.

Hook fishing

Fishing with hooks is carried out with the "cannete" and the "palamito or parangale". In the first case, thin rods with lines and baited hooks are used, which are fixed to the bottom of the pond at dusk. When the sun rises, the equipment is checked and, if there is a bite, the fish is hauled in and the baited hook is re-set. The 'palamito', on the other hand, is a long line with numerous baited hooks that is lowered while waiting for the catch, and can have more than 200 hooks. In contrast to a 'reed boat', a longline is completely hauled in, re-trimmed and lowered while waiting for a new catch.

title.rendered: I fassoni (fassonis or fassõis in Sardinian)

content.rendered:
The ‘fassoni’ are traditional boats typical of navigation and fishing in the lagoons of the Sinis area, used by ‘palamitai’, i.e. fishermen who used the ‘palamito’ (a long, thin fibre or nylon rope to which numerous hooks are tied at right angles) and the spear.

They have flat bodies about 4 metres long and 1 metre wide, with the bow thinner and arched upwards.

It is capable of carrying only two fishermen and fishing equipment.

This very old boat, in use in the pond of Santa Giusta until the beginning of the 20th century, was driven with a long pole in shallower waters and with two oars in deeper areas (the boat in this case has an entrance for the oars called ‘Su Scrammu’).

In the first case the fassõis are called ‘A Cantòi’ and the pole is made of three rods tied together, while the fassõis used where the waters are deeper are called ‘a remusu’.

They have flat bodies about 4 metres long and 1 […]

content.rendered:
They were made from bundles of lake rushes joined together in such a way as to make the prow pointy and the stern truncated; to consolidate the structure, a framework of reeds was inserted inside the bundles.

In mid-June, when the moon was waning, the fisherman would mow the plants needed to build the boat and, after letting them dry for five or six days according to the methods useful for its manufacture (neither too dry nor too wet), he would build his boat. 

He started with the central bundle, to which the lateral bundles were added in odd numbers, usually seven or nine, depending on the thickness of the reed.

Because of the fragility of the boat, 3 or 4 fassõis were needed every year.

In mid-June, when the moon was waning, the fisherman would mow the plants needed to build the boat […]

They were made from bundles of lake rushes joined together in such a way as to make the prow pointy and the stern truncated; to consolidate the structure, a framework of reeds was inserted inside the bundles.

In mid-June, when the moon was waning, the fisherman would mow the plants needed to build the boat and, after letting them dry for five or six days according to the methods useful for its manufacture (neither too dry nor too wet), he would build his boat. 

He started with the central bundle, to which the lateral bundles were added in odd numbers, usually seven or nine, depending on the thickness of the reed.

Because of the fragility of the boat, 3 or 4 fassõis were needed every year.

title.rendered: What was fishing with fassõis like?

content.rendered:
The fishermen would place a long pole called ‘su cantoni’ on the bottom of the pond in order to slide the boat through the water and manoeuvre it while fishing. 

Once they had reached the chosen location, they would lower their equipment (usually lines and nets) and then return to collect their catch. 

In addition to static fishing, the fishermen, still on board the fassonis, also practised fishing with a spear, hunting for prey.

Once they had reached the chosen location, they would lower their equipment (usually lines and nets) and then return to collect their catch. 

In addition to static fishing, the fishermen, still on board the fassonis, also practised fishing with a spear, hunting for prey.

content.rendered:
This regatta takes place on the first Sunday in August when the sun sets and sees the participants compete in the Santa Giusta pond. 

The importance of this event is the promotion and enhancement of the traditions of the lagoon town of Santa Giusta.

A week before the regatta, in fact, the local government promotes various cultural initiatives, such as workshops for the construction of Is fassonis aimed at children, gastronomic events, musical performances, exhibitions and guided excursions. 

Shortly before the competition, there is a parade of fishermen carrying and showing Is fassonis to the public, followed by a parade of groups dressed in traditional costumes. 

Before the actual regatta, the gozzi (cius in Sardinian), flat-bottomed wooden boats also used in the open sea, compete.

The competition is based on the speed and skill of the participants, who have to stand on the boat, pushing it by means of a pole that sinks into the bed of the pond.

Shortly before the competition, there is a parade of fishermen carrying and showing Is fassonis to the public, followed by a parade of groups dressed in traditional costumes. 

Before the actual regatta, the gozzi (cius in Sardinian), flat-bottomed wooden boats also used in the open sea, compete.

The competition is based on the speed and skill of the participants, who have to stand on the boat, pushing it by means of a pole that sinks into the bed of the pond.
